BA.name: Batting Average
BA.definition: Batting average measures the percentage of a batter's at-bats that result in a hit. MLR Reference requires players to have 2 PA per team game to qualify for the leaderboards.

sections.title: Calculation
sections.content:
The formula is:

BA = Hits / At Bats

OBP.name: On-Base Percentage
OBP.definition: On-base percentage measures the percentage of a batter's plate appearances that result in the player reaching base. This includes hits and walks, but does not include reaching on a fielder's choice (which only happens in very rare situations in MLR).

sections.title: Calculation
sections.content:
The formula is:

(Hits + Walks) / (At Bats + Walks + Sacrifice Flies)

SLG.name: Slugging Percentage
SLG.definition: Slugging percentage measures a hitter's power by weighting hits based on the number of bases. A double is worth twice as much as a single, a triple three times, and a home run four times. Slugging percentage can be interpreted as the average number of total bases a player records in an at-bat.

sections.title: Calculation
sections.content:
The formula is:

SLG = Total Bases / At Bats

OPS.name: On-Base Plus Slugging
OPS.definition: OPS is a combination of On-Base Percentage (OBP) and Slugging Percentage (SLG). It is intended to combine a hitter's ability to get on base with their ability to hit for power into a single metric.

sections.title: Calculation
sections.content:
The formula is:

OPS = On-Base Percentage + Slugging Percentage

ISO.name: Isolated Power
ISO.definition: ISO measures a hitter's raw power by calculating their extra bases per at-bat. It is the difference between Slugging Percentage and Batting Average.

sections.title: Calculation
sections.content:
The formula is:

ISO = Slugging Percentage - Batting Average

BABIP.name: Batting Average on Balls In Play
BABIP.definition: BABIP measures a player's batting average exclusively on balls they hit into the field of play, excluding home runs and strikeouts. Because MLR has no fielding component, BABIP is not a very meaningful metric.

sections.title: Calculation
sections.content:
The formula is:

BABIP = (Hits - Home Runs) / (At Bats - Strikeouts - Home Runs + Sacrifice Flies)

WPA.name: Win Probability Added
WPA.definition: WPA measures a player's contribution to their team's win probability. It credits or debits a player for how much their action in a plate appearance changed the likelihood of their team winning the game. WPA is taken directly from the gamelogs. WPA is treated as a zero-sum game, where a credit to a batter will identically be debited to the pitcher and vice versa.

RE24.name: Run Expectancy Over 24 Base-Out States
RE24.definition:
RE24 is an advanced statistic that measures the total impact a player has on their team's run-scoring potential. It calculates the change in run expectancy from the beginning of a plate appearance (or stolen base attempt) to the end, crediting or debiting the player for the outcome.

Unlike stats that only measure hits or outs, RE24 captures the full context of a play. For example, a solo home run is good, but a bases-clearing double that doesn't score the batter is often more valuable in a given situation. RE24 quantifies this value.

sections.title: Interpretation
sections.content:
RE24 is a counting stat, not a rate stat. It accumulates over a season.

  • For Hitters: A higher RE24 is better. It means the player consistently creates situations that lead to more runs. A positive value indicates they have been more productive than an average player would have been in the same situations.
  • For Pitchers: A lower RE24 is better. It means the pitcher consistently reduces the opponent's chances of scoring. A negative value indicates the pitcher has been more effective at suppressing run-scoring opportunities than an average pitcher.

A value of 0 represents a league-average performance.

sections.title: Calculation in MLR
sections.content:
The formula for a single play is:

RE24 = (Run Expectancy After Play) - (Run Expectancy Before Play) + (Runs Scored on Play)

The calculation process in this tool is as follows:

  1. Run Expectancy (RE) Matrix: First, the tool calculates a Run Expectancy Matrix for each season. This matrix contains the average number of runs that will be scored from every possible base-out state (e.g., "runner on 1st, 0 outs") until the end of the inning. There are 24 possible states (8 base states x 3 out states). The Run Expectancy Matrix is calculated empirically from all innings in a season. Because of this, the matrix can and will change over the course of the season, and is likely to be inaccurate early in a season. Also, a player's RE24 may change without a player recording another plate appearance (or stolen base attempt) or batter faced.
  2. Before and After States: For every single plate appearance in the season, the tool looks at the base-out state before the play and the state after the play.
  3. Applying the Formula: The tool retrieves the RE values for the before and after states from the matrix and applies the formula above. Any runs that score directly on the play are also added.
  4. Aggregation: A player's seasonal RE24 is the sum of the RE24 values from all of their plate appearances (or stolen base attempts).

WAR.name: Wins Above Replacement
WAR.definition:
Wins Above Replacement (WAR or cheWAR) is a comprehensive statistic that attempts to consolidate a player's total contribution into a single number. In general, it represents how many more wins a player is worth than a "replacement-level" player, a hypothetical, readily-available player (e.g., a minor leaguer) who could be substituted at minimal cost. However, MLR does not take considerable skill, so WAR should actually be Wins Above Average (WAA). This would cause many players to have negative WAR even if they've made meaningful contributions to their team's success, so "replacement level" has been arbitrarily defined to mimic MLB.

In this tool, WAR is built upon the foundation of RE24, providing a holistic view of a player's value in the context of the league's run-scoring environment. MLR does not have a fielding component, so a player's value solely lies in how good a player is at producing or preventing runs.

sections.title: Interpretation
sections.content:
WAR provides a convenient way to compare the total value of all players, regardless of whether they are a hitter or a pitcher.

  • 0.0 WAR: A replacement-level player.
  • 0.2 WAR: A solid, everyday player.
  • 0.6+ WAR: An All-Star caliber player.
  • 1.0+ WAR: An MVP candidate.

Since this is a counting stat, these values are benchmarks for a full season. A player's WAR accumulates over time.

sections.title: Calculation in MLR
sections.content:
The WAR model in this tool is designed to be balanced and context-neutral.

WAR = (Runs Above Replacement) / (Runs Per Win)

Here is the step-by-step process for a given season:

  1. Total WAR Pool: The total amount of WAR available for all players in the league for a season is defined as (Number of Regular Season Games) * 6.17. MLB typically has ~1000 WAR over the course of a season, or 1000 / 162 = 6.17 WAR / Game. Since S3, there is 98.72 cumulative WAR available across MLR.
  2. Hitter/Pitcher Split: To ensure fair comparison, this total WAR pool is split evenly, with 50% allocated to all hitters and 50% to all pitchers.
  3. Runs Per Win (RPW): A standard value of 10 Runs Per Win is used. This means for every 10 runs a player creates above a replacement player, they are credited with 1 WAR.
  4. Runs Above Replacement (RAR): This is the core of the calculation.
    • First, a player's Runs Above Average (RAA) is their `RE24` for the season.
    • Next, a "replacement-level" run value is calculated based on the total WAR pool and total playing time (Plate Appearances and Batters Faced) in the league.
    • A player's RAR is their `RAA` plus the replacement-level value scaled by their specific playing time.
    • RAR = RE24 + (Replacement Value per PA/BF * Player's PA/BF)
  5. Final Value: The player's total RAR is divided by 10 (the RPW value) to arrive at their final WAR for the season.

OPS+.name: On-base Plus Slugging Plus
OPS+.definition: OPS+ is an advanced statistic that measures a hitter's total offensive value, adjusted for the overall offensive context of the league in a given season. It normalizes a player's On-base Plus Slugging (OPS) so that 100 is always the league average.

sections.title: Interpretation
sections.content:
• 100: Exactly league average.
  • 150: 50% better than the league average hitter.
  • 75: 25% worse than the league average hitter.

OPS+ is a great way to compare players across different seasons and ballparks, as it accounts for variations in both league-wide offensive performance and park effects.

sections.title: Calculation in MLR
sections.content:
The formula used for OPS+ in this tool is:

OPS+ = 100 * ( (Player's Park-Neutral OBP / League's Park-Neutral OBP) + (Player's Park-Neutral SLG / League's Park-Neutral SLG) - 1 )

To achieve a park-neutral statistic, the calculation uses the 'Result at Neutral' column for seasons where it is available (S3 and later). This column shows what the outcome of the play would have been in a perfectly average ballpark.

This approach ensures that OPS+ correctly compares players by adjusting for both league-wide offensive trends and ballpark effects.

Career OPS+ is calculated using the same logic, but with the player's career park-neutral OBP and SLG measured against a career league-average OBP and SLG (weighted by the player's plate appearances in each season). This ensures a more accurate reflection of career value than averaging seasonal OPS+ values.

W.name: Win
W.definition: A single pitcher on the winning team is awarded a Win.
conditional_rules:
Case 1: Starting Pitcher Earns the Win
To qualify for the Win, a starting pitcher must pitch at least 3 and 1/3 innings, which is scaled from MLB's requirement of pitching 5 innings in a 9 inning game.
Their team must have the lead when the pitcher leaves the game.
That lead must never be given up for the rest of the game.

Case 2: Relief Pitcher Earns the Win (Starter Doesn't Qualify)
The starting pitcher pitches less than 3 and 1/3 innings.
The team has the lead when the starter leaves, and they never give it up.
The win is awarded to the first relief pitcher to record at least one out.

Case 3: Relief Pitcher Earns the Win (Lead Change)
The game is tied or the pitcher's team is behind when they are in the game.
While that pitcher is still the pitcher of record, their team takes the lead.
The team never gives up that lead.

L.name: Loss
L.definition: A single pitcher on the losing team is awarded a Loss.
conditional_rules:
Case 1: Pitcher Allows the Go-Ahead Run
A pitcher allows one or more runs to score, which gives the opposing team a lead.
The opposing team never gives up that lead for the rest of the game.
This pitcher is charged with the loss.

Case 2: Pitcher Leaves Runners on Base
A pitcher leaves the game with one or more runners on base.
Those runners later score, and one of them is the run that gives the opposing team a lead they never give up.
The pitcher who allowed those runners to get on base is charged with the loss.

SV.name: Save
SV.definition: A single relief pitcher on the winning team can be awarded a Save. The pitcher who gets the Save cannot also get the Win.
conditional_rules:
Case 1: The "Standard" Save
The pitcher is the final pitcher for the winning team.
They enter the game with a lead of 3 runs or less.
They pitch for at least 1 full inning.

Case 2: The "Tying Run" Save
The pitcher is the final pitcher for the winning team.
They enter the game with the potential tying run already on base, at bat, or on the on-deck circle.

Case 3: The "Long Relief" Save
The pitcher is the final pitcher for the winning team.
They pitch for at least 3 innings to finish the game. Due to MLR only having 6 inning games, this type of save is exceptionally rare.

HLD.name: Hold
HLD.definition: One or more relief pitchers can be awarded a Hold in a game. A pitcher cannot get a Win or a Save in the same game as a Hold.
conditional_rules:
A relief pitcher enters the game in a "save situation" (see the glossary entry for 'SV').
They record at least one out.
They leave the game with their team still in the lead.

ERA.name: Earned Run Average
ERA.definition: The average number of earned runs a pitcher allows per six innings pitched. It is the most common statistic for evaluating a pitcher's performance.

sections.title: Calculation
sections.content:
The formula is:

ERA = (Earned Runs * 6) / Innings Pitched

WHIP.name: Walks and Hits per Inning Pitched
WHIP.definition: WHIP measures how many baserunners a pitcher allows per inning pitched.

sections.title: Calculation
sections.content:
The formula is:

WHIP = (Walks + Hits) / Innings Pitched

FIP.name: Fielding Independent Pitching
FIP.definition: Fielding Independent Pitching (FIP) is an advanced pitching metric that estimates a pitcher's performance based only on outcomes that do not involve the defense: home runs, walks, and strikeouts. It operates on the same scale as ERA, making it easy to compare. Because MLR does not have a fielding component, FIP is not a very meaningful stat.

sections.title: Interpretation
sections.content:
Because FIP is on the same scale as ERA, you can read it in the same way. A FIP of 3.50 is roughly equivalent to a 3.50 ERA. The key difference is that FIP measures what a pitcher's ERA should have been, given their performance on events they can control.

  • If FIP < ERA: The pitcher may have been unlucky or had poor defensive support.
  • If FIP > ERA: The pitcher may have been lucky or had excellent defensive support.

sections.title: Calculation in MLR
sections.content:
The formula used for FIP in this tool is:

FIP = ((13 * HR) + (3 * BB) - (2 * K)) / IP + FIP Constant

  • HR: Home Runs Allowed
  • BB: Walks Allowed (does not include Hit By Pitch, as HBP is not tracked)
  • K: Strikeouts
  • IP: Innings Pitched

To ensure FIP is on the same scale as ERA, a FIP Constant is calculated for each season and added. This constant is derived from the league's overall performance in a given season:

FIP Constant = League ERA - ((13 * League HR) + (3 * League BB) - (2 * League K)) / League IP

This adjustment ensures that a league-average FIP will equal the league-average ERA for that season, making for a fair comparison.

ERA+.name: Earned Run Average Plus
ERA+.definition: ERA+ is an advanced statistic that measures a pitcher's performance, adjusted for the overall offensive context of the league and park in a given season. It normalizes a pitcher's Earned Run Average (ERA) so that 100 is always the league average, but unlike traditional ERA, a higher number is better.

sections.title: Interpretation
sections.content:
• 100: Exactly league average.
  • 150: 50% better than the league average pitcher.
  • 75: 25% worse than the league average pitcher.

ERA+ is the pitching equivalent of OPS+ and is one of the best ways to compare pitchers across different eras, seasons, and ballparks.

sections.title: Calculation in MLR
sections.content:
The formula used for ERA+ in this tool is:

ERA+ = 100 * (League's Park-Neutral ERA / Player's Park-Neutral ERA)

Calculating a pitcher's Park-Neutral ERA (`nERA`) is a complex process:

  1. Neutral Simulation: Each inning a pitcher has thrown is re-simulated using the 'Result at Neutral' to determine what would have happened in an average ballpark.
  2. Inherited Runner Accountability: The simulation is careful to only hold pitchers accountable for runners they put on base. Runs scored by inherited runners are not counted against a pitcher's `nERA`.
  3. Responsibility for Runners Left on Base: When a pitcher exits mid-inning, they are still responsible for the runners they leave behind. To account for this, the simulation uses the Run Expectancy (RE) Matrix to calculate the probable number of runs that will score. It intelligently separates the run expectancy of inherited runners from the pitcher's own runners, ensuring the pitcher is only charged for the run potential they created.

This comprehensive simulation produces a pitcher's `nERA`, which reflects their performance independent of park effects. This `nERA` is then compared against the league-average `nERA` to produce the final ERA+.

Career ERA+ is calculated using the same logic, but with the player's career park-neutral ERA (`nERA`) measured against a career league-average `nERA` (weighted by the player's innings pitched in each season). This provides a more accurate career value than averaging seasonal ERA+ values.
